Key Arguments: The legislation poses a threat to democracy and freedom of speech.
The Bill grants excessive power to unelected bureaucrats without transparency or accountability.
The criteria for determining misinformation or disinformation are not clearly defined.
The Bill could criminalize criticism of government communication, infringing on fundamental freedoms.
There is a risk of bias and manipulation in determining misinformation.
The Bill lacks sufficient safeguards for freedom of expression and privacy.
Notable Quotes: If this is not done, it will be a strong indicator that democracy and freedom of speech in this country is no longer a real thing.
The Bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats to silence speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.
This reeks of a communistic nature of governing.
The few provisions that have been included to acknowledge the competing right to freedom of expression are tokenistic.
